Colin, I read through both your posts on speciation.  There is
definitely r=
oom for innovation on the way that most NEAT
implementations (including my =
own) currently partition species, which
is not very sophisticated.  

My im=
plementation currently chooses a single representative of each
species and =
new individuals in the population are compared with the
list of representat=
ives in order.  The new individual is placed in the
first species with a re=
presentative that is within the compatibility
distance.  

One other thing =
some people don't realize is that my implementation
sorts the genomes in ea=
ch species in order of their fitness, which
means ultimately that the repre=
sentative becomes the individual with
highest fitness.

I bring that up bec=
ause I think it's an interesting question whether a
species should be "anch=
ored" to one of its earliest exemplars, or
whether it should be centered ar=
ound its most fit member.  

Intuitively, the idea that individuals are par=
titioned into species
based on a principled clustering algorithm seems bett=
er than simply
placing them into the species with the first matching repres=
entative
(it may be worth checking the clustering algorithms that are out
t=
here).  The "borders" of species would be less overlapping with the
cluster=
ing approach.  

However, I feel less certain about the idea of anchoring s=
pecies.  In
nature, species certainly are free to drift in character.  Of c=
ourse,
we don't have to do things like nature and should not take it as a
r=
ule, but it does raise why anchoring should help?  The alternative in
which=
 species are centered around their most fit individual (who can
change) see=
ms potentially superior.  What do you think, Colin?  After
all, I would rat=
her have a species defined by a competent member than
the first barely-func=
tional pioneer who happened to come on the scene.

So I like the clustering=
 idea, but I am not sure about the anchoring
aspect.

Finally, the idea of =
keeping a queue of old species and keeping
evolution away from those areas =
is also interesting.  However, I am
not sure that it would have much effect=
 because it seems unlikely that
evolution would end up back in an old part =
of *genotypic* space (which
is what speciation measures), considering that =
genomes are changing in
topology.  To get back to an old topology from a lo=
ng time ago seems
unlikely.  So while it shouldn't hurt, it is an interesti=
ng question
whether the old queue will get used very often.

By the way, ju=
st for definitional clarification, keeping a queue of
old species differs f=
rom the "novelty search" that Joel Lehman and I
have been working on, becau=
se our approach focuses on novel behaviors,
not novel genotypes (and it ign=
ores fitness).  A novelty search
through the space of genotypes is more lik=
e an exhaustive enumeration,
since any given genotype can be explored simpl=
y by setting its genes
to the desired parameters.  In behavior space, in co=
ntrast, you cannot
simply get to a new behavior by specifying that behavior=
.  You have to
find it.

Overall, I am glad to see an exploration of more s=
ophisticated
speciation strategies.  I think the coolest thing would be for=
 the
user to be able to select the way speciation works from among several
=
options. I am looking forward to seeing your new version of SharpNEAT!

ken=



--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Colin Green" <colin.green1@...> wrote:
>
>=
 Here are some thoughts on speciation that probably don't warrant a
> deep =
discussion but I post them for the record.
> 
> Currently sharpneat takes a=
 casual approach to speciation and I'm
> wondering if there are improvement=
s to be had. This ties in with my
> recent post about genome compatibilty m=
etrics and euclidean/manhattan
> distance.
> 
> In sharpneat v2 I'm trying =
to make the code base more abstract and
> re-usable, e.g. I'm separating th=
e NeatGenome and EvolutionAlgorithm
> classes from being dependent on each =
other and also using generics so
> that we can plug in new genomes or algor=
ithms with minimum effort.
> Thus my previous discussion resulted in my cre=
ating an
> ICompatibilityMetric<TGenome> interface which can be plugged in =
to the
> NeatEvolutionAlgorithm.
> 
> Looking at speciation again I see tha=
t at the outset I simply assign
> genomes to species if they are within som=
e distance and if not then I
> place the new genome in its own species. Ind=
ependent of this I also
> adjust the compatibility threshold once per gener=
ation in an attempt
> to keep the species count between some limits (which =
has its own
> problems and is another email in the making). A possible prob=
lem with
> this approach is that the first attempt at speciation will proba=
bly
> just assign the first N genomes in the population as being the first
=
> genome in each species - these genomes then become [temporary]
> exemplar=
s for the species, that is, the remaining genomes are compared
> against th=
em and if they are close enough to an exemplar they are
> assigned to that =
species.
> 
> As an alternative approach I was thinking of taking the discu=
ssion
> about compatibility (or distance) metrics a step further and actual=
ly
> explicitly representing where genomes are in the encoding space with
>=
 something like an IEncodingSpace interface, the idea being that I take
> t=
he total number of unique connection IDs in the whole population as
> being=
 the number of spacial dimensions, I then define the location of
> each gen=
ome in each dimension as being the connection weight for that
> ID (using 0=
 if a genome doesn't have a connection for agiven ID). From
> here I can fi=
nd the range/limits of locations (weights) in each
> dimension, which effec=
tively defines an enclosing hypercube that the
> current population is insi=
de. I can now divide up the hypercube into
> equally sized sub-cubes in ord=
er to find clusters of genomes that are
> close together and use this as th=
e basis of my initial set of species.
> 
> In addition to all that I suspec=
t it makes sense to keep the exemplar
> for each species consistent through=
out the life of the species - so a
> genome (representing a point in space)=
 we keep to one side, that may
> have been removed from the population long=
 ago. This keeps each
> species 'anchored' in space and prevents it from dr=
ifting. We then
> have the choice of keeping a FIFO buffer of dead species =
as an
> indicator of parts of the search space that have recently been
> se=
arched - avoiding these spaces when creating new genomes. This is an
> idea=
 I raised a few years ago and which I think is known as novelty
> search.
>=
 
> Colin.
>
